Think of the front wheel of a bicycle as a circle of radiusr. Let's neglect the thickness of a tire, the size of the sensor, and all physical effects. The sensor is placed on the rim of the wheel, that is, on some fixed point on a circle of radiusr. After that the counter moves just like the chosen point of the circle, i.e. moves forward and rotates around the center of the circle.At the beginning each participant can chooseanypointbi, such that his bike is fully behind the starting line, that is,bi<si-r. Thus, the counter records that the participant made a complete ride in timetfi-tsi.Maxim is good at math and he suspects that the total result doesn't only depend on his maximum speedv, but also on his choice of the initial pointbi. Now Maxim is asking you to calculate for each ofncompetitions the minimum possible time that can be measured by the time counter. You are given $n$ competitions, each with a starting point $s_i$ and a finish point $f_i$.  A cyclist rides a bike with a wheel of radius $r$ and a maximum speed $v$.  The cyclist can choose any starting point $b_i$ behind the starting line ($b_i < s_i - r$).  

The cyclist starts at $b_i$, accelerates to their maximum speed, and the timer starts when the sensor on the bike wheel reaches the starting line ($s_i$). The timer stops when the sensor reaches the finish line ($f_i$).

Find the minimum time it takes for the cyclist to complete each competition.

A cyclist races a set number of times. Each race has a starting and ending point. The cyclist's bike has a wheel of a given radius. The cyclist starts before the starting line and accelerates to their maximum speed. The time it takes to complete the race is measured from when the bike's wheel sensor passes the starting line to when it passes the ending line.  Find the minimum time it takes to complete each race, given the cyclist's maximum speed and the wheel radius.
